prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

div.p: In this guide, you’ll learn the basics of opening, customizing and managing your new online store. Shopify provides you with a variety of tools to make your venture into your business easy and customizable.
Join the millions of active users selling their products or services using Shopify.
With the Shopify platform we will take you from buisness concepts to sharing your buisness vision to the world.
Establish a buisness name, purchase or transfer a domain, and construct your brand by using our free tools.

p.b: Sell your products or services anywhere

div.p: With the Shopify platform you will be able to sell anywhere your customers are. You will have the flexability to access your ecommerce store online, and in-person.
With the Shopify platform, marketing will be at your fingertips with built-in tools that will allow you to roll out Facebook and Google campaigns while allowing you to analyze their success.
With the Shopify dashboard you will be able to easily see all aspects of your buisness, manage your orders and process them from start to finish.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

p.div: The Pricing PlansShopify offers different pricing plans based on your individual needs as an entrepreneur. Detailed below are what each plan offers. https://www.shopify.com/pricing

concept.title: Getting Started
concept.shortdesc: How to get started with Shopify

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: To get started using Shopify you have to settle on what it is you are going to sell and how you would like your store to look. You will be able to follow this guide to begin the process of selling your product to the public.
Follow this video for a simple and quick explanation on how to create your account:

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: To begin selling your services or products, you have to have an store. Within this section you will learn how to properly setup your store to reach your potential customers.

task.title: Setting up the Basics
task.shortdesc: Your new storefront must start somewhere, so here's how you can get started.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, go to Settings.
Click General.
Locate the Store Details section and fill in all the necessary information.
Click Save.

task.title: Adding Store Policies
task.shortdesc: Policies are important so that your customers know how you handle refunds, privacy, and terms of service for transactions. Store policies are added on a different webpage, but will be displayed as links at the bottom of the customer checkout page for your store. This requires 2 separate browser tabs to be open.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page click on Pages
On your Pages page, click Create a New Page
In a separate tab, access your store checkout settings. Copy each policy to your computers’ clipboard.
Back to the first page, paste the clipboard contents. Then click Save Page.
Add a link to the policies page so your customers can easily find it.

task.title: Add a menu and links to your store
task.shortdesc: With how prevalent social media and the use of other sites are in today's day and age, you’ll likely want to link external sites and accounts to your shopify storefront.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, go to Online Store > Navigation.
On the Navigation page, click the name of the menu you want to edit.
Click Add menu item.
Two input fields will appear. In the Name field, enter the name of the link you want to add. This is what will be displayed.
From the drop-down menu beside the link name, select the link type that best describes the link you’re inputting.
Click Save menu.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, click on the Products tab to go to the Products page.
Click Add Product to begin the process of adding in new products.
Enter in the details and logistics for your new product.

task.title: Organizing Products
task.shortdesc: Shopify allows you to create product collections to organize your products however you’d like through the use of collections. Examples of categories: Clothes for men, women, or children Items on sale Items of a certain type, size or color Seasonal products

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, click on Collections
On the Collections page, click on Create Collection
In the new window, enter a Title and Description for the collection. This is a mandatory step.
Under Sales Channels make sure to choose which channels you want the collection to be listed under. (I.E. Shopify online store, Facebook, Amazon, etc.)
Collections allow you to choose whether products will be added in manually or automatically. This option cannot be changed later.

substep.cmd: If you chose automatically: Add in the selection criteria under Conditions.
If you chose manually: When adding in products manually at a later time, make sure you click Save after adding them. You can add the same product to several different collections.

step.cmd: Click Save Collection

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: After you choose a theme that defines the basic look and feel of your online store, you can customize the theme to suit your unique brand. You can customize your theme settings from your Shopify admin by using the theme editor. The theme editor includes a theme preview and a toolbar that you can use to add and remove content, and to make changes to your settings. To learn about which settings are available for your theme, see your themes documentation.
If your theme doesn't include settings for the changes that you want to make and you are comfortable with HTML, CSS, and Liquid, then you can edit your theme code.

concept.title: Domains
concept.shortdesc: Now that you have your store setup, you will a need a way to show this store to your customers. This is where having a domain comes in.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: A domain is the website address that customers can visit to browse and purchase from your store online. With Shopify you have a few options for domains depending on your preferences and starting point.
You can have a domain through Shopify. An example of the URL for this is examplestore.myshopify.com.
Alternatively, you can have a custom domain which you can either purchase a new URL or have one transferred to Shopify. An example of a URL for this is examplestore.com.

task.title: Domain Through Shopify
task.shortdesc: Shopify has the ability to host your online store through either a third-party domain or one that’s been bought from us.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: Navigate to the domain purchasing page, on shopify.
To see if the domain name you want is available click Domain Search and type the domain in the text box. Click Generate domains to search.
If the domain name is available, or an alternative is, choose which one you want, but be sure to look at the yearly price as well, since different domains have different prices.
Follow the prompts from there and if fully seen through, you’ll have a new domain for your Shopify shop!

task.title: Add Existing Domain
task.shortdesc: Shopify also allows you to add existing domains from third party providers. If you'd rather do that than purchasing one of Shopify's, here are the steps in doing so.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, go to Online Store > Domains
Click Connect Existing Domain
Enter the third party domain you own, then click Next.

task.title: Setting up your existing domain to connect to Shopify
task.shortdesc: Shopify gives you the option to add in your own domain, if it already exists.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: Navigate to your domain provider and log into your account on that site.
Find your DNS Settings. These are generally located in the domain management area on the site, but this varies from provider to provider.
Once you find the DNS Settings, edit your A record to point to Shopify’s IP address 23.227.38.65 (Copy and paste this into the field).
Save the A record.
In the DNS settings, find the CNAME record
Change your www CNAME record to point to shops.myshopify.com (copy this as well).
Save the CNAME record.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, click Verify connection to verify that your domain has been connected to your store.

task.title: Set your primary domain
task.shortdesc: The primary domain of your storefront is the domain name that customers see in the browser’s address bar.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, go to the Online Store > Domains.
In Primary Domain, click Change primary domain.
Select the domain you would like set as the primary from the prompt.
Click Save.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin page, go to Online Store > Domains.
In Third-party domains, locate the domain you want to remove and click Remove.
Click Remove again to confirm.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: To remove a shopify domain, you mustcontact support to do so.

concept.title: Selling Products
concept.shortdesc: Now that you have your store created, the next step is to populate your store with products or services to be presented to your customers.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: With the Shopify platform you will have the ability to reach your customers via your website online and in person.
Customers will be able to reach your site from their web browser directly or through Facebook campaingns.
You will also be able to sell to customers face to face. This will allow you to easily expand or establish a physical store front or booth.

concept.title: Selling in Person
concept.shortdesc: Shopify offers you the ability to sell both online and in person, expanding the possibilities for your business to grow.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: Despite the fact that Shopify focuses on e-commerce, it also offers business owners a full retail store experience with Shopify POS app. This app allows you to create carts for customers, accept a range of payments and methods, track orders and inventory across retail locations, online stores and whatever other active sales channels you’re running.

task.title: Setting up the Shopify POS app

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

note.b: Before you start adding products and setting up your payments, there are a few administrative tasks that you should do:

ul.li: If you want to sell in person, then check with your local laws to see if the Shopify POS system is compliant in your country.
Complete the initial setup so that your store address, email address, and other store settings are up to date.
Know where to manage your account and access your billing information.
Add staff accounts so that each of your staff members has a personal login account and all sensitive account information remains secure.

step.cmd: Configure your basic administrative settings
Download the Shopify App

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu
Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: Click the + button next to the Sales Channels heading in your Shopify admin.
Click the name of the sales channel you want to add in the Add sales channel dialog.
Click Add channel.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: Click Settings on the Shopify admin, and then click Sales channels.
Find the name of the sales channel you want to remove.
Click remove channel

concept.shortdesc: With the Shopify platform you will be able to seemlessly add, and edit your customers information.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

concept.title: Managing Customers
concept.shortdesc: We are now getting to one of the most impoartant part of your buisness, your customers. In this section we will cover how to manage and edit specific parts of your customers' profiles.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: New customers will have their names and information added to customer lists when they place an order in your store, allowing you to email them using their profile information. You are also able to add, edit, or delete customer profiles manually in certain circumstances. Using this information, you can create a customer group for sending emails or discounts to customers.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: Go to the Customers page from the Shopify Admin, and click the Add customer button.
Input the information on the form, updating the checkboxes as necessary

substep.cmd: Customer accepts marketing means that the customer has agreed to receive newsletters or marketing emails.

Collect tax details if you are charging a sales tax for the customer. Depending on the customer’s, or your own location, there will be additional options or information, such as tax exemption options with Browse or search exemptions.

step.cmd: After filling out all the appropriate information, click Save customer to create or update the customer profile.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: On the Shopify Admin, click the Customers button, and select the profiles of the customers you want to email.
Click the customer’s email address in the Customer overview, and then edit the subject as necessary ( {{ shop.name }} can be used to automatically generate your store’s name in an email).
Type your message in the message field, and if you want to keep a copy for records, enter the email you want the copies sent to in the Send bcc to field.
Click the Review email when you are done, and then click Send notification if you are satisfied with the message, or Back if you want to revise the message.

concept.title: Edit Customers
concept.shortdesc: Now that you have some customters you might be asked to edit some of their information. This section will walk you throught the process of editing the basic information of your customers.

Click the name of the customer profile you want to edit.
In the Customer overview section, click Edit.
step.info:

First name.

Change the customer's address details and click Save.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

context.p: Using tags can help you organize your customer profile list. You can use tags to label your customers with categories or descriptive terms. For example, if you have wholesale customers, then you can tag those customers as wholesale.

step.cmd: From your Shopify admin, go to Customers
Click the name of the customer profile you want to edit.
In the Tags section, add or edit your customer profile tags in the text box.
Click Save to confirm your changes.

task.title: Customer's Note
task.shortdesc: A customer note contains information that you might want to keep track of for a particular customer profile. Notes are visible to store staff only, so your customers won't see them.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

step.cmd: From your Shopify admin, go to Customers.
Click the name of the customer profile you want to edit.
Under Customer Note, add or change existing notes in the text box, and click Save.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p:
New orders will appear in the orders page when a customer makes a purchase from one of your online stores or sales channels. Orders are categorized into 3 different states in the processing flow:
Order has been placed (Capturing payments): This occurs when customers use a credit/debit card to purchase and order. During this time, the bank is processing the purchase and determining whether the funds can be spent or not.
Order has been paid (Fulfilling order): At this point, it’s up to you to ship their order, hence why this process is referred to as order fulfillment.
Order has been fulfilled and paid (Archive the order): The order has been both paid for and shipped. The customer has received their order, so there’s no need to process the order further.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

conbody.p: The overview shows you the overall status of all the orders placed by customers. Customers are given the option to receive links to their order status page by email. The email sent to them is a template that includes the page URL the order status page that tells them:

context.p: Customization is formatted using HTML, so if you need help understanding how it works, check out this simple guide.

step.cmd: From the Shopify Admin Page, go to Settings > Notifications.
Locate the Email Templates section, then find the Order confirmation and Shipping confirmation email templates.

compare how well your sales channels are performing

Payment methods are further customizable by storefront owners, as they can choose which type of payments to accept and decline, as well as methods based on if transactions take place in real life, or over the online storefront.These options include:

li.p: Manual card payments (customer enters in card details manually)

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

li.p: On the Orders screen, tap the search icon.
In the search field, enter in either the order ID, receipt number, or customer name. Results will appear beneath the search bar.

Choose the order of the item that needs to be refunded.

context.p: Once all constraints are satisfied, tap Refund then Done.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

section.title: What is Shopify’s IP address?
section.p: When using a third-party or external domain for your shop, usually you must state shopify’s IP address for the third-party provider. If so, it is 23.227.38.65. This IP will need to be set as your A record on the other site.

title.b: How do I change my myshopify.com domain?

section.p: You cannot because your myshopify.com domain is a URL that is a unique identifier for your store, therefore it can’t be changed or removed. However, it can be replaced with a custom domain name.

title.b: Why isn’t my Shopify POS synced with my Shopify Admin?

section.p: The Shopify POS app usually updates automatically with any changes made on the admin page, but if you find the desktop and mobile apps aren’t synced with the same information, you can force the app to resync with the Shopify admin.
From the Shopify POS app, press your Ipad’s home button to send the app into the background.
From the Ipad’s home screen, find and tap the Shopify POS app.
Check to see if the app has been updated with the new changes.
If the app still hasn’t updated, force close the app, then reopen it.
Double tap the home button to bring up all of the running apps on the Ipad.
Located the shopify app and swipe the window up until the window has left the screen.
Tap the home button again, then located the Shopify POS app and tap it open.

prolog.author: Ryan Ewaskiew, Jason Figueroa, Carter Francis, Mailie Liu

section.title: Website Domain
section.p: The name of the website or URL, sometimes called the host name. A web domain is an actual presence on the Internet, such as a web page. A web domain name is a substitute that replaces the Internet Protocol (IP) address. For example, we can replace the IP address 207.97.195.109 with a domain name such as www.shopify.com.

section.title: Traffic Sources
section.p: A report that provides an overview of the different kinds of sources that send people to your website.

li.p: Direct Traffic:People who show up to the site by directly using the URL associated with it or from using a bookmark.
Social: Other websites that send traffic over to you. These are commonly through social media sites such as Twitter and Facebook where the URL for the storefront is shared.
Email: Traffic from emails that included links to the URL.

ul.li: Unknown: Traffic from places that cannot be determined. This is a common category.
